textContent:
"After 42 years of providing children a safe place to be while their parents worked, Student Care @ Children‚Äôs Society (SCC) in Bukit Merah View will close its doors on 31 December 2021.

The seeds for SCC were sown in the late 1970s when then-Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew expressed concern about ‚Äúlatchkey children‚Äù ‚Äì children who typically wore their house keys around their necks so they could let themselves into their homes after school. These children often returned to empty houses, and fended for themselves until their parents returned from work.

Through the decades, the Student Care service model has evolved with greater emphasis on supporting children from disadvantaged families with school-based student care. This is now available in almost all primary schools. The Ministry of Education is also expanding the After School Engagement programmes for both primary and secondary school students. Within Bukit Merah, many community agencies also provide similar services through their student care centres. This allows us to shift our focus to other needed programmes. We will work with community agencies to explore how we can continue to support the children and young persons living in the area in other ways.

On behalf of all past and present beneficiaries, thank you to the staff and volunteers who have kept the centre going for over four decades, and created fond memories to last a lifetime! ‚ú®
"
name: Singapore Children's Society

textContent:
"#casestory
At a young age, Alisah* was separated from her parents due to their incarceration and has been living in Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society since then. Due to the separation, it created some resistance and anxiety in meeting her birth parents when they were first released from prison. Over time, Alisah built up her trust with them, only to be disappointed when her parents got caught for taking drugs again. 

The adversities caused Alisah difficulties in keeping up with her studies and she developed maladaptive ways to cope with her struggles such as hitting her head against the wall. Despite the unfavourable family circumstances and various health concerns, Alisah showed great tenacity and resilience. With the help of care workers at Sunbeam Place @ Children‚Äôs Society, she managed to cope better and developed good moral values. 

Help us to continue providing beneficiaries like Alisah, a safe and nurturing space to develop and grow. A donation of $50 can help cover the transportation costs for a child. Start impacting lives here> https://lnkd.in/geRRR2i
